questions.text: Match the following condition with its appropriate diagrammatic representation. Disorder Figure A.Accreta 1. B.Percreta 2. C.Increta 3.
questions.explanation:
Placenta accreta spectrum

Description

Placenta accreta

Villi is firmly adherent to the endometrium

Placenta increta

Villi invades the myometrium

Placenta percreta

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

Placenta Accreta Type

Management

Partial Placenta Accreta
  • Remove as much placenta as possible.
  • Use oxytocics to control bleeding.

Total Placenta Accreta
  • Complete family: Perform hysterectomy.
  • Incomplete family:
    • Leave the placenta for autolysis within the uterus and administer antibiotics.
    • Consider uterine artery embolisation or Methotrexate therapy.

Placenta Percreta with Bladder Invasion

Perform hysterectomy with partial cystectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the most common developmental anomaly of the placenta?
questions.explanation:
• Multiparity
  • Maternal age more than 40 years
  • Asian race
  • Presence of uterine scar
  • Prior curettage
  • Prior placenta previa
  • Multiple pregnancies

Condition

Description

Succenturiate placenta

(Option A)

 
  • Extra lobes form separate from the main placental body within the membranes, connected to it by fetal vessels and membranes.
  • It occurs only in 5 % of placentas

Bilobed Placenta

 

Placenta with two roughly equal lobes separated by a membrane.

Placenta accreta spectrum

(Option C)

 
  • Occurs when the placenta is abnormally adherent to the uterine wall after childbirth.
  • The spectrum has 3 conditions:
    • Accreta
    • Increta
    • Percreta
  • It occurs in 1 out of 2500 pregnancies

Ring-shaped Placenta (Option D)

 

An annularly shaped placenta, often resembling a horseshoe due to partial atrophy, is rare.

Placenta Membranacea

 

A rare condition where chorionic villi cover fetal membranes either partially or completely, occupying the periphery of the chorion.

Circumvallate Placenta

Placenta with raised edges composed of chorion, amnion, and fibrin deposits and associated with poor pregnancy outcomes.

Circummarginate Placenta

Similar to the circumvallate placenta but with a flat transition from membranous to villous chorion.

Battledore Placenta

 
  • An umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than in the center.
  • It is associated with pregnancy complications like preterm labor and fetal distress.
Placenta spuria
  • Unequal placenta not connected by vessel

  • Succenturiate placenta
  • Placenta accreta spectrum
  • Ring-shaped Placenta
  • Placenta membranacea
  • Bilobed Placenta
  • Circummarginate Placenta
  • Battledore Placenta

questions.text: A 35-year-old G2P1 pregnant woman undergoes an ultrasound showing a single umbilical artery. Which of the following is associated with the given finding?
Match the following images to the specific insertion of the umbilical cord: Image Diagnosis a) Fucrate insertion 2. b) Eccentric insertion 3. c) Velamentous insertion 4. d) Marginal insertion
questions.explanation:
Types of abnormal cord insertion

Properties
  1. Marginal insertion

 
  • Marginal cord insertion occurs when the umbilical cord is within 2cm or less from the edge of the placenta.
  • Also known as battledore placenta.
  • Occurs in about 6% of singleton gestations and 11% of twin pregnancies.
  • It rarely causes problems but may result in the cord being pulled off during placenta delivery.
  • In monochorionic twins, it may be associated with weight discordance.

2. Eccentric insertion

 
  • Eccentric insertion occurs when a lateral insertion is >2 cm from the placental edge.
  • This variant of umbilical cord insertion generally poses no identifiable fetal risk.

3. Velamentous insertion:

 
  • This condition is characterised by umbilical vessels travelling within the membranes before reaching the placental margin.
  • Incidence of approximately 1% in singleton pregnancies and 6% in twin pregnancies.
  • Can be diagnosed antenatally via ultrasound.
  • The presence of a velamentous Cord at the level of internal Os is known as VASA PREVIA.
  • It can cause fetal bleeding and death during delivery.

4. Fucrate insertion

 
  • Umbilical vessels lose their protective Wharton jelly shortly before insertion.
  • They are covered only by an amnion sheath, making them prone to compression, twisting, and thrombosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 37 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with painless vaginal bleeding. Her vital signs are stable, and fetal heart tones are reassuring. An ultrasound performed earlier in the pregnancy indicated placenta previa. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Give IV steroids and Rest in a High-Risk Ward

options.label: D
options.text: PV examination was done in OT

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 32 weeks gestation presents with painless vaginal bleeding. An earlier ultrasound showed a low-lying placenta, and the non-stress test revealed a sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern with a heart rate of 100 bpm. Maternal vital signs are stable. What is the most appropriate test to determine the source of the bleeding?

A 28-year-old primigravida delivers a full-term baby vaginally after an uncomplicated pregnancy. During the first diaper change, the nurse notices bright red blood in the neonatal stool. The baby appears healthy and is feeding well. Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to determine whether the blood is of maternal or fetal origin?

A 32-year-old multiparous woman has just delivered a healthy baby boy vaginally. The obstetrician is now managing the third stage of labour and is observing for signs of placental separation. Which of the following signs is the most definitive sign of placental separation?

options.label: A
options.text: Permanent lengthening of the umbilical cord

options.label: B
options.text: A gush of blood from the vagina

questions.correct_answer: A. Permanent lengthening of the umbilical cord

questions.text: What is the most common cause of maternal mortality in India?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Maternal Mortality

Causes

Percentage (%)

Hemorrhage:

  • Majorly- Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Other - Antepartum, retained placenta, ectopic pregnancies (Option A)

20-25

Infection (Option C)

15-20

Hypertension - Eclampsia, Pre eclampsia (Option B)

12-15

Unsafe Abortion (Option D)

10-13

Obstructed Labour

8

Anemia

15-20

Other indirect causes (Viral Hepatitis)

5-10

questions.text: All of the following are recommended during postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) blood loss management EXCEPT:

options.label: C
options.text: Ensuring APTT <1.5 times the normal range

options.label: D
options.text: Routine use of recombinant activated factor VII (rFVIIa)

questions.correct_answer: D. Routine use of recombinant activated factor VII (rFVIIa)

questions.text: Which is the most common variety of abruptio placenta?
questions.explanation:
Revealed
  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed
  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.
  • Blood collects within the uterus, causing increased pressure and pain without visible bleeding.

Mixed
  • Involves both concealed and revealed bleeding.
  • There is both internal and external bleeding, with some blood exiting through the vagina and some collecting behind the placenta.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents with severe abdominal pain and per-vaginal bleeding. The uterus is tender, the pulse rate is 110 bpm, and BP is 90/60 mm Hg. Fetal heart sounds are absent. What grade of abruptio placentae is she suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic sonographic finding of Morbidly Adherent Placenta (MAP)?

options.label: C
options.text: Disruption of the bladder-uterine serosal interface

questions.correct_answer: B. Thickening of the retroplacental myometrium
